meanings.definition: To live on or in a host organism and obtain nutrients at the host's expense.
meanings.sent1: The tick can parasitise the dog by feeding on its blood.
meanings.sent2: Some plants parasitise nearby trees to get the nutrients they need.
meanings.sent3: The lazy roommate would parasitise off his friends' food without contributing.
meanings.sent4: Her negative thoughts would parasitise her mind, draining her of happiness.
meanings.sent5: The idea of jealousy can parasitise relationships, causing harm.

meanings.definition: To exploit the hospitality of others for one's own benefit.
meanings.sent1: Some people parasitise their friends by always asking for favors.
meanings.sent2: He would parasitise his colleagues by constantly borrowing money.
meanings.sent3: The clever raccoon managed to parasitise the picnic by stealing all the food.
meanings.sent4: Her charm allowed her to parasitise the party, getting free drinks all night.
meanings.sent5: The politician tried to parasitise the goodwill of the community for personal gain.
